study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether heat therapy could attenuate muscle atrophy in STZ-induced diabetic rats and explore its mechanism of action on specific muscle proteins.
results_summary: Heat therapy significantly improved neuromuscular function, reduced muscle atrophy by 34.3% (3 weeks) and 44.1% (6 weeks), decreased atrophy markers (CD68, KLF, MAFbx), and elevated hypertrophy markers (AKT, mTOR, HSP70) in diabetic rats.
population_specificity: Male Sprague Dawley rats with STZ-induced diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of heat therapy on pain intensity, duration of labor during the first stage, and Apgar scores.
results_summary: Heat therapy significantly reduced pain intensity and shortened the duration of the first stage of labor, while also improving Apgar scores at the 5th minute compared to standard therapy.
population_specificity: Women in the first stage of labor.
study_duration: Duration of the first stage of labor (not explicitly stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to gather a consensus among European experts on the role of heat therapy in musculoskeletal pain, including its mechanisms, efficacy, safety, and optimal use.
results_summary: Consensus was reached on 78% of statements, supporting heat therapy's mechanism of action, effectiveness in chronic musculoskeletal pain, and safety. Low consensus was found for its role in acute pain and preventing muscular damage in athletes.
population_specificity: European experts (116 surveyed) and implied focus on individuals with musculoskeletal pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of heat therapy, alone and combined with whole-body vibration (WBV), on muscle strength, flexibility, and balance in middle-aged and elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that heat therapy combined with WBV resulted in the largest improvements in flexibility, while both WBV and WBV plus heat therapy groups showed significant pretest-posttest differences in flexibility and muscle strength. Heat therapy alone was not as effective as when combined with WBV.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and elderly participants with no regular exercise habits.
effective_dosage: Heat therapy involved lowering a heat pack at 73 °C to 40-43 °C (wrapped in multiple layers of towels) before application; duration not specified beyond the 20-30 min range.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of 6 weeks of localized heat therapy on human skeletal muscle mitochondria to single-leg interval training, focusing on mitochondrial respiratory capacity and fatty acid oxidation.
results_summary: Heat therapy significantly improved mitochondrial respiratory capacity by 24.8%, comparable to exercise training, but unlike exercise, it did not enhance fatty acid oxidation or citrate synthase activity.
population_specificity: Thirty-five subjects with interventions localized to the quadriceps muscles of the right leg.
effective_dosage: Heat therapy administered 3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether unsupervised, home-based leg heat therapy (HT) using water-circulating trousers improves walking performance in patients with symptomatic lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found that HT significantly improved 6-minute walk distance compared to sham treatment, with no significant differences in secondary outcomes. HT was deemed safe, well-tolerated, and clinically meaningful for walking tolerance in PAD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether heat therapy using natural thermal mineral water could improve glycaemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so no results are reported in the abstract. The primary endpoint will be the change in glycated haemoglobin from baseline to week 12.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
effective_dosage: 30-minute bath sessions in 38°C natural thermal mineral water (group A) or thermoneutral water (30°C-32°C) (group B), up to 5 weekly visits averaging 50-60 visits over 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of nourishing Yin and clearing heat therapy (NYCH therapy) combined with Western medicine in treating radiotherapy-induced oral mucositis in nasopharyngeal carcinoma patients.
results_summary: NYCH therapy combined with Western medicine delayed the onset of oral mucositis, reduced severe cases, improved treatment efficacy, and alleviated xerostomia compared to Western medicine alone.
population_specificity: Patients with nasopharyngeal carcinoma undergoing radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if heat therapy could serve as an alternative to exercise for improving hepatic mitochondrial function and glucose regulation in patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease.
results_summary: The study proposes heat therapy as a viable alternative to exercise for enhancing liver mitochondrial function and glucose control in nonalcoholic fatty liver disease patients, though specific efficacy data are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether local heat therapy could serve as a potential therapeutic strategy for granulomatous lobular mastitis (GLM) by comparing its efficacy and safety to existing therapies.
results_summary: Local heat therapy significantly shortened the median first remission time compared to corticosteroid therapy (5.30 vs. 11.27 months), though remission and recurrence rates were similar across treatments. It showed mild adverse effects and shorter healing times but requires further confirmation.
population_specificity: Patients with granulomatous lobular mastitis (GLM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of ultrasound deep heat therapy (UST) on pain and joint function in patients with adhesive capsulitis compared to no treatment, placebo, or other therapies.
results_summary: UST significantly improved pain scores when combined with exercise and/or other physical modalities compared to placebo, but its effects on disability and range of motion were uncertain.
population_specificity: Patients with adhesive capsulitis (glenohumeral joint synovial inflammation and capsular fibrosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether raising body temperature through heat therapy (using a commercial Jacuzzi) could reduce seizures and improve social behavior in a child with drug-resistant epilepsy caused by an A350V IQSEC2 missense mutation.
results_summary: The study found that raising the child's body temperature via a Jacuzzi dramatically reduced his seizures and appeared to improve his social behavioral interactions.
population_specificity: A single child with drug-resistant epilepsy due to an A350V IQSEC2 missense mutation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of passive heat therapy on glycemic and cardiovascular parameters, as well as body weight, in patients with Type-2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in hemoglobin A1c, fasting glucose, or triglyceride levels after passive heat therapy, though slight improvements in certain cardiometabolic parameters were noted. Further research with longer intervention periods is needed to confirm potential benefits.
population_specificity: Patients with Type-2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of superficial heat therapy in managing non-specific mild-to-moderate low back pain (LBP) by reviewing its mechanisms and published evidence.
results_summary: The study found that continuous, low-level heat therapy provides pain relief, improves muscular strength, and increases flexibility in patients with acute or chronic non-specific LBP. It is described as an effective, safe, easy-to-use, and cost-effective non-pharmacological option.
population_specificity: Patients with acute or chronic non-specific mild-to-moderate low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of local heat therapy versus cold rub gel on pain and joint function in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Heat therapy significantly improved pain severity, joint symptoms, ADL function, and Sport and Recreation function in patients with knee osteoarthritis, though no significant difference was found in Knee-related QOL. Both heat therapy and cold rub gel were effective in improving pain and joint function.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis (n=117).

study_goal: To investigate whether a single session of local heat therapy (HT) accelerates glycogen resynthesis and muscle function recovery after prolonged intermittent shuttle running.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in glycogen content, muscle function recovery, or muscle soreness between legs treated with HT and control legs. HT did not enhance recovery compared to the control condition.
population_specificity: 26 trained individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on heat therapy's effectiveness and safety for treating cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) and compare it to standard treatments like meglumine antimony.
results_summary: Heat therapy showed promising results comparable to meglumine antimony for CL treatment, with very low side effects localized to the treatment area, suggesting it as a safe alternative. The study recommends further randomized clinical trials to compare different heat therapy methods and standard treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL).
effective_dosage: Not specified (various heat sources like radiofrequency, ultrasound, infrared, etc., were reviewed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether heat therapy could serve as a conservative treatment to attenuate the progression of peripheral artery disease (PAD) and prevent plantar ulcers.
results_summary: Heat therapy showed potential to stimulate the cardiovascular system, generating acute responses similar to exercise, which may reduce walking fatigue in PAD patients and impede ulcer development. Early findings suggest chronic exposure could lead to beneficial adaptations.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD), particularly those at risk of plantar ulcers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing literature on heat therapy, focusing on its molecular mechanisms and cardiovascular benefits.
results_summary: The study found robust and widespread beneficial effects of heat therapy on cardiovascular health, supported by a growing body of evidence. The review highlighted the potential of chronic, repeated heat exposure (e.g., hot baths or saunas) to improve cardiovascular outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of heat therapy on blood pressure and vascular function in healthy and clinical populations through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: Heat therapy reduced mean arterial, systolic, and diastolic blood pressure and improved vascular function (measured via brachial artery flow-mediated dilatation). Early evidence also suggested benefits for arterial stiffness and cutaneous microvascular function, though resting heart rate remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Healthy and clinical populations.
effective_dosage: Heat exposure for 30-90 minutes, over 10-36 sessions.
study_duration: Varied by study, ranging from 10 to 36 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish a safe and effective heat therapy method for targeting deep intra-articular tissues in the human knee using a resonant cavity applicator.
results_summary: The study observed increased temperature around cartilage tissue without heating overlying layers, and no adverse reactions were reported during heating with up to 20 W of power. The results suggest potential safety and effectiveness for knee osteoarthritis treatment.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers (n=3)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single session of leg heat therapy (HT) could improve exercise tolerance, blood pressure, and inflammatory markers in patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: Heat therapy significantly reduced systolic blood pressure and post-exercise endothelin-1 levels, with a trend toward increased peak walking time, though claudication onset time and other inflammatory markers remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Sixteen patients with symptomatic PAD (average age 65 ± 5.7 years, ankle-brachial index 0.69 ± 0.1).
effective_dosage: Single 90-minute session of HT using liquid-circulating trousers perfused with warm water.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether heat therapy (HT) could mitigate fat accumulation, improve vascular growth, mitochondrial biogenesis, and skeletal muscle function in obese mice with induced peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: HT reduced fat mass by ~25-29% compared to controls, prevented weight gain, and improved muscle strength in the EDL but not the SOL. However, it did not affect skeletal muscle capillarization, angiogenic factors, mitochondrial content, or gracilis artery diameter.
population_specificity: Male diet-induced obese (DIO) C57Bl/6J mice with femoral artery occlusion.
effective_dosage: Lower-body immersion in water heated to 39°C for 30 minutes daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze how passive heating (heat therapy) induces autophagy and its potential therapeutic implications for chronic disease and aging.
results_summary: The study suggests that passive heating may stimulate autophagic function, as evidenced by in vitro and in vivo models, and discusses its potential to restore dysfunctional autophagy in chronic disease and aging.
population_specificity: In vitro, animal, and human models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of 6 weeks of localized heating on skeletal muscle strength, volume, and contractile properties in healthy humans.
results_summary: The study found that repeated localized heating did not significantly affect muscle cross-sectional area, pennation angle, evoked peak twitch amplitude, rate of torque development, or maximal voluntary isometric or isokinetic torque in active participants.
population_specificity: Fifteen active participants (8 males/7 females, 35 ± 6 years, 70 ± 14 kg, 173 ± 7 cm, average training of 87 min per week).
effective_dosage: Heat pads applied for 8 h/day, 5 days/week, increasing muscle temperature by 4.6 ± 1.2 °C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the current evidence for heat therapy's effectiveness in improving walking ability and quality of life in patients with intermittent claudication (IC).
results_summary: Whole-body immersion significantly improved 6-minute walk distance and ankle-brachial pressure indices, but no form of heat therapy improved quality of life or brachial blood pressure. Acute interventions showed transient physiological changes but lacked long-term efficacy data.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication (IC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether changes in skin surface temperature from heat therapy (thermotherapy) were associated with pressure pain tolerance thresholds in healthy individuals.
results_summary: Heat therapy significantly altered skin surface temperature, but no significant changes in pain tolerance thresholds were observed, and there was little association between temperature changes and pain tolerance.
population_specificity: 22 healthy university students aged 18-35 years.
effective_dosage: Application of heated gel bags for 20 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential role of heat therapy in treating and preventing Alzheimer's disease by targeting metabolic, vascular, and chaperone systems.
results_summary: Heat therapy was shown to reduce insulin resistance, improve vascular function, activate interorgan communication, and enhance mitochondrial function and proteostasis, suggesting potential clinical benefits for Alzheimer's disease patients. However, future human studies are needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Patients suffering from or at risk of Alzheimer's disease (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 6 weeks of supervised leg heat therapy (HT) improved walking performance, vascular function, and quality of life in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) compared to a sham treatment.
results_summary: The study found that HT did not improve 6-minute walk distance, blood pressure, or vascular function but did lead to a clinically meaningful increase in perceived physical function and a reduction in serum endothelin-1 levels. Adherence to HT was high, and the treatment was well tolerated.
population_specificity: Symptomatic peripheral artery disease (PAD) patients (age: 68 ± 8 years; ankle-brachial index: 0.6 ± 0.1).
effective_dosage: 3 times per week using water-circulating trousers perfused with water at 48°C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether local heat therapy accelerates functional recovery after strenuous eccentric exercise by improving glycogen resynthesis, vascular function, mitochondrial activity, and muscle protein synthesis.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that heat therapy may enhance recovery by addressing delayed muscle refueling, microvascular dysfunction, and mitochondrial impairment, though specific results are not detailed.
population_specificity: Individuals experiencing muscle impairment after eccentric exercise (specific demographics not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms and clinical benefits of heat therapy (HT) on skeletal muscle adaptations, including angiogenesis, hypertrophy, mitochondrial biogenesis, and glucose metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that HT activates intracellular signaling networks, promotes skeletal muscle remodeling, and may enhance capillary growth, mitochondrial function, insulin sensitivity, and reduce muscle wasting. Translational studies suggest these benefits apply to humans.
population_specificity: Rodents and human skeletal muscle (specific human population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of heat therapy, alone and combined with a foot massager, in reducing the severity of Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS) symptoms and improving sleep and quality of life.
results_summary: Heat therapy alone significantly improved sleep scale scores compared to no intervention, but its effects on RLS severity and quality of life were not statistically significant. Combined with a foot massager, heat therapy showed additional benefits in symptom severity and sleep quality.
population_specificity: Twenty-eight patients with diagnosed, bothersome Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and analyze the clinical outcomes of thermal therapy (≤1.4°C increase in core body temperature) in patients with heart failure (HF).
results_summary: Thermal therapy significantly improved NYHA class, LVEF, endothelial function, blood pressure, cardiothoracic ratio, oxidative stress markers, and quality of life in HF patients. The therapy also reduced cardiac death and rehospitalization rates.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure (HF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential therapeutic benefits of heat therapy and heat acclimation in upregulating heat shock proteins (HSPs) to mitigate neurodegeneration.
results_summary: The study suggests that heat therapy may increase HSP expression, which could protect against protein aggregation in neurodegenerative diseases. Broader physiological benefits, such as improved muscle function and cerebral blood flow, were also noted, though direct evidence in patient populations is limited.
population_specificity: Primarily healthy populations, with some implications for individuals with neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's and Parkinson's.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the isolated effects of circulating serum factors from heat therapy on endothelial cell function, particularly angiogenesis and nitric oxide bioavailability.
results_summary: Serum collected after acute and 8-week heat therapy improved endothelial cell angiogenesis, which was NO-mediated, and increased endothelial NOS (eNOS) abundance. Sham serum had no effects.
population_specificity: 20 healthy young adults (22 ± 1 years).
effective_dosage: 36 sessions of hot water immersion (session 1 peak rectal temperature: 39.0 ± 0.03°C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether repeated passive heat exposure (heat therapy) could reduce cardiovascular risk factors in women with obesity and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
results_summary: Heat therapy significantly reduced muscle sympathetic nerve activity, blood pressure, C-reactive protein, total cholesterol, arterial wall thickness, and improved flow-mediated dilation following ischemia-reperfusion stress, indicating substantial cardiovascular benefits. No changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Women with obesity and PCOS (n=18, age 27±4 yr, BMI 41.3±4.7 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of repeated local heat therapy on skeletal muscle function, capillarization, and mitochondrial content in humans.
results_summary: Heat therapy enhanced knee extensor strength, increased endothelial nitric oxide synthase and small heat shock proteins, and averted declines in capillarization around type II fibers, but did not affect mitochondrial content or fiber cross-sectional area.
population_specificity: Twelve young adults (23.6 ± 4.8 years, BMI 24.9 ± 3.0 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 90 minutes per session, 5 days per week, using a garment perfused with water at ~52°C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of ultrasound heat therapy and low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in reducing pain associated with temporomandibular joint disorders (TMDs).
results_summary: LLLT showed statistically significant better outcomes than ultrasound heat therapy in reducing pain and improving mouth opening in TMD patients. The mean pain score and mouth opening measurements favored LLLT over ultrasound therapy.
population_specificity: 42 patients (age 25-45 years) with TMD-related pain and no underlying bony pathology.
study_duration: 15 therapy sessions (duration per session not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether heat therapy (HT) could improve skeletal muscle function in a mouse model of ischemia-induced muscle damage, simulating peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: HT at 37°C and 39°C improved soleus muscle mass and maximal force, with 39°C showing the most significant increase in relative muscle mass. A single HT session also enhanced mRNA expression of myogenic factors in the soleus, but not the EDL muscle, indicating muscle-specific effects.
population_specificity: Male 42-week-old C57Bl/6 mice with femoral artery ligation (ischemia-induced muscle damage model).
effective_dosage: Immersion in water baths at 37°C, 39°C, or 41°C for 30 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine changes in metabolic function in obese women with PCOS following repeated passive heat exposure (heat therapy).
results_summary: Heat therapy improved fasting glucose, glucose AUC, insulin AUC, adipocyte insulin signaling, and reduced serum testosterone in obese women with PCOS, with no changes observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Obese women with PCOS (age: 27 ± 1 yr, BMI: 41.3 ± 1.1 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if heat therapy (via hot-water immersion) is a viable alternative to traditional exercise for improving functional ability and cardiovascular health in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: Both heat therapy and supervised exercise improved walking distance and reduced resting blood pressure in PAD patients over 12 weeks, with no significant differences between the two interventions. Heat therapy was well-tolerated and had excellent adherence.
population_specificity: Individuals with peripheral arterial disease (PAD), mean age ~75 years, mixed gender.
effective_dosage: Spa bathing at ~39°C, 3-5 days/week for ≤30 minutes, followed by ≤30 minutes of callisthenics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the evidence on heat therapy as a treatment for primary dysmenorrhea.
results_summary: Heat therapy showed favorable effects on menstrual pain compared to unheated placebo, analgesic medication, and no treatment, though results were based on few trials with small sample sizes. The review suggested effectiveness but highlighted the need for more rigorous trials.
population_specificity: Women with primary dysmenorrhea (menstrual pain without pelvic pathology).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of passive heat therapy (PHT) and moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on skeletal muscle capillarization, endothelial-specific eNOS content, mitochondrial density, GLUT4, and IMTG content in sedentary males.
results_summary: PHT increased capillary density, capillary-fiber perimeter exchange index, and endothelial-specific eNOS content similarly to MICT but did not improve mitochondrial density, GLUT4, or IMTG content. Both interventions improved aerobic capacity and insulin sensitivity.
population_specificity: Young sedentary males (21 ± 1 yr, BMI 25 ± 1 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 40-50 minutes at 40°C in a heat chamber, 3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether local heat therapy (HT) accelerates functional recovery and enhances the expression of angiogenic factors in skeletal muscle after eccentric exercise in humans.
results_summary: HT improved fatigue resistance and increased the expression of angiogenic factors (VEGF and angiopoietin 1) compared to a thermoneutral control, but did not affect peak torque recovery, capillarization, or macrophage content.
population_specificity: Eleven untrained individuals (23.8 ± 0.6 years old).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimum temperature for heat therapy to treat Meibomian gland dysfunction by analyzing lipid disorder in meibum at different temperatures.
results_summary: Heating meibum to 40–41.5°C increased lipid disorder to 90%, potentially alleviating dry eye symptoms. Higher temperatures (52–59°C) were needed for severe cases (MHSCT), but safety concerns were noted.
population_specificity: Donors with Meibomian gland dysfunction (MMGD), post-hematopoietic stem cell transplant dry eye susceptibility (MHSCT), and healthy donors (Mn).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mild heat pretreatment or serum from heat therapy participants could protect endothelial cells against oxidative and inflammatory stress induced by hypoxia-reoxygenation (H/R).
results_summary: Both mild heat (39°C) and serum from heat therapy subjects independently prevented H/R-induced NF-κB activation and superoxide production, while only serum attenuated IL-6 release. Heat therapy also increased HO-1 protein, suggesting a protective mechanism against oxidative and inflammatory stress.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (in vitro) and serum from 10 human subjects who underwent heat therapy.
effective_dosage: Heat therapy was administered four to five times per week, increasing rectal temperature to ≥ 38.5°C for 60 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how heat therapy could improve or restore cardiovascular and metabolic health in obese individuals by targeting adipose tissue dysfunction, inflammation, and ischemia.
results_summary: The study suggests that heat therapy may improve cardiometabolic health in obese individuals through mechanisms like heat shock proteins, hypoxia-inducible factor 1α, and hemodynamic effects, potentially reversing metabolic dysfunction and insulin resistance.
population_specificity: Obese individuals with metabolic dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether heat therapy could effectively reduce labor pain compared to a control group.
results_summary: The study found that heat therapy significantly reduced labor pain severity at 60 and 90 minutes post-intervention compared to the control group, with statistically significant differences (p < 0.05).
population_specificity: Primiparous women aged 18-35 years.
study_duration: Until cervical dilatation reached 8 cm (timing not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of radiofrequency-induced heat therapy as an alternative treatment for cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) compared to the toxic standard treatments.
results_summary: The study found that heat therapy administered via a Thermomed™ 1.8 instrument in a single application was effective for treating CL with minimal toxic effects, offering a significant improvement over traditional antimonial drugs.
population_specificity: Patients with cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a closed-loop neural network controller in regulating laser-induced heat therapy for breast tumors while minimizing damage to healthy cells.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that the trained artificial neural network effectively adjusted laser power to achieve the desired temperature increase in the tumor center, showing promising performance in simulation studies. The approach successfully minimized excessive temperature rise in healthy cells.
population_specificity: Simulation-based study using a physiological model of breast tumor mass with nanoparticles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on the effectiveness of heat therapy for primary dysmenorrhea, focusing on pain reduction and quality of life.
results_summary: Heat therapy showed evidence of pain reduction in primary dysmenorrhea, but no study included quality of life as an outcome. The methodological quality of heat therapy trials was moderate (6.3/10 on the PEDRO scale).
population_specificity: Individuals with primary dysmenorrhea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of heat therapy combined with tissue culture to eliminate phytoplasmas from infected raspberry and blackberry plants.
results_summary: Heat therapy followed by tissue culture successfully eliminated phytoplasmas from all treated raspberry and blackberry plants, as confirmed by qPCR testing after cultivation periods of 231 to 565 days. The results suggest this method is effective for producing phytoplasma-free Rubus mother plants in nurseries.
population_specificity: Phytoplasma-infected raspberry (25 plants) and blackberry (33 plants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplemental heat wrap therapy improves biomechanical parameters (range of movement and strength) in patients with chronic low back pain within a multimodal treatment concept.
results_summary: The study found that heat wrap therapy, when added to multimodal treatment, further improved trunk strength parameters (extension and rotation) but did not enhance flexibility compared to multimodal treatment alone.
population_specificity: 176 patients with chronic low back pain.
effective_dosage: Several hours a day (heat wrap therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of passive heat therapy on microvascular function and whether improvements were linked to changes in nitric oxide bioavailability.
results_summary: Heat therapy significantly improved cutaneous microvascular function by enhancing NO-dependent dilation, with no changes observed in the sham group. The local heating plateau and NO-dependent dilation increased notably in the heat therapy group.
population_specificity: Young, sedentary, otherwise healthy subjects (n=18).
effective_dosage: Hot water immersion to maintain rectal temperature ≥38.5°C for 60 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 8 weeks of repeated hot water immersion (heat therapy) improves biomarkers of cardiovascular health in young, sedentary humans.
results_summary: Heat therapy significantly improved flow-mediated dilatation, reduced arterial stiffness, lowered blood pressure, and decreased carotid intima media thickness, with effects comparable to or greater than exercise training. No changes were observed in the sham group.
population_specificity: Young, sedentary humans
effective_dosage: Immersion in a 40.5°C bath sufficient to maintain rectal temperature ≥ 38.5°C for 60 minutes per session, 4-5 times per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of heat therapy versus contrast therapy in reducing pain, swelling, and improving range of motion in grade I and II lateral ankle sprains during the subacute phase.
results_summary: Heat therapy reduced pain more effectively than contrast therapy immediately after application but increased swelling. After 3 days of continuous application, heat therapy showed no significant difference in pain reduction or ROM compared to contrast therapy but continued to increase swelling.
population_specificity: 115 participants of both genders with grade I or II lateral ankle sprains, assessed starting on the fifth day of injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and mechanisms of heat therapy (sauna and hot tub) for treating obesity and diabetes, and to propose a provisional guide for its use.
results_summary: Heat therapy reduced fasting glycemia, glycated hemoglobin, body weight, and adiposity in human studies, with animal studies suggesting nitric oxide and heat shock protein 70 as potential mechanisms for improved insulin sensitivity and inflammation.
population_specificity: People with type 2 diabetes mellitus and obesity.
effective_dosage: Sauna (80-100°C) or hot tub (40°C) for 15 min, three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acute effects of lower body heating (LBH) and unilateral thigh heating (TH) on angiogenic signaling and heat shock protein expression in healthy young individuals.
results_summary: Both LBH and TH increased the expression of factors associated with capillary growth in human skeletal muscle, including VEGF, ANGPT2, and HSPs, but did not significantly alter circulating angiogenic cytokines or bone marrow-derived proangiogenic cells. LBH also reduced FOXO1 expression, while TH did not affect CX3CL1, FOXO-1, or PF4 levels.
population_specificity: Healthy young individuals
effective_dosage: Not specified (temperature changes: LBH increased core temperature to 37.4°C and leg skin temperature to 39.6°C; TH increased leg skin temperature to 40.3°C)
study_duration: Acute (30 minutes for LBH, 90 minutes for TH)

study_goal: To compare the effects of two warm compress devices on ocular temperature, tear film stability, and participant preference in mild-to-moderate dry eye.
results_summary: Both devices significantly increased eyelid temperature, lipid layer grade, and tear film stability, with the MGDRx Eye Bag showing greater temperature elevation and being preferred by most participants.
population_specificity: 41 subjects with mild-to-moderate dry eye symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of moist or dry heat therapy applied to the perineum during delivery in reducing perineal injuries requiring suturing and to assess its safety regarding newborn adaptation.
results_summary: Heat therapy did not significantly reduce perineal suturing, though moist heat showed better perineal outcomes. Neonatal safety, measured by Apgar scores, was unaffected by the therapy.
population_specificity: 198 pregnant women undergoing normal delivery in 5 Catalan hospitals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to observe hemodynamic changes (blood pressure and pulse rate) in patients receiving Sarvanga Swedana, a form of heat therapy, in an Ayurvedic clinical setting.
results_summary: The study found a significant increase in blood pressure and pulse rate immediately after therapy, but with continued use in a subgroup, there was a significant reduction in systolic blood pressure and pulse rate.
population_specificity: Patients routinely receiving Sarvanga Swedana in a Panchakarma setting at an Ayurvedic hospital.

study_goal: To investigate the effects of local heat therapy on chest pain intensity, duration, frequency, and opioid analgesic need in patients with acute coronary syndrome.
results_summary: Local heat therapy at 50°C significantly reduced chest pain intensity, duration, and frequency compared to placebo (37°C). No significant difference was found in opioid analgesic need between groups before or after the intervention.
population_specificity: 66 patients with acute coronary syndrome from a coronary care unit in Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of heat therapy for reducing pain and increasing satisfaction during the active phase of physiological labor.
results_summary: Heat therapy significantly reduced pain scores and increased satisfaction scores compared to the control group, with both results being statistically significant (P < 0.05).
population_specificity: Primiparous women aged 18-35 years old.
study_duration: Applied during the first stage of labor (duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Hederagenin (HDG) could alleviate kidney injury and inflammation in acute kidney injury (AKI) models and elucidate its mechanism of action via the LncRNA-A330074k22Rik/Axin2/β-catenin signaling axis.
results_summary: HDG effectively reduced cisplatin-induced kidney injury and inflammation in mice and suppressed the expression of LncRNA-A33, which in turn inhibited the Axin2/β-catenin signaling pathway, improving AKI outcomes.
population_specificity: Mice with cisplatin-induced AKI and LPS-stimulated renal tubular epithelial cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether Hederagenin (HE) protects against renal fibrosis and to uncover its underlying mechanism, particularly its interaction with the M3 receptor.
results_summary: HE inhibited proliferation and fibrosis in TGF-β-treated NRK-49F cells by targeting the M3 receptor, and this effect was reversed by the M3 receptor agonist pilocarpine, suggesting a potential therapeutic role for HE in renal fibrosis.
population_specificity: TGF-β-treated NRK-49F fibroblasts (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of hederagenin on reducing blood lipids and oxidative stress in oleic acid-induced HepG2 cells and hyperlipidemic rats, and to explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Hederagenin significantly increased triglyceride (TG) clearance in vitro and effectively reduced TC, TG, LDL-C, and MDA while increasing HDL-C, SOD, and GSH-PX in hyperlipidemic rats. The mechanism may involve inhibition of lipid absorption, reduction of lipid oxidation, and down-regulation of p38MAPK phosphorylation.
population_specificity: Oleic acid-induced HepG2 cells and hyperlipidemic rats.
effective_dosage: 250 μmol/L (in vitro), dosage in vivo not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Hederagenin (HG) could protect against sepsis-induced acute lung injury (ALI) by reducing inflammation and inhibiting macrophage M1 polarization, potentially via the NF-κB pathway.
results_summary: HG administration improved survival rates, reduced lung injury, decreased inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-6, MCP-1, iNOS, COX-2), and inhibited M1 macrophage polarization in both in vivo and in vitro models, likely by suppressing NF-κB and NLRP3 inflammasome activation.
population_specificity: Rats with sepsis-induced ALI and PMA-differentiated THP-1 macrophages stimulated with lipopolysaccharide.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, skin permeation, and effectiveness of a topical ointment containing hederagenin glucoside saponins (SS) and chromane-derived hydrazone (TC2) for treating canine cutaneous leishmaniasis (CCL).
results_summary: The ointment (2% TC2-2% SS) showed no acute dermal toxicity, achieved skin permeation, and produced a complete long-term clinical cure in 56 dogs without adverse effects, with no disease recurrence over 24 months.
population_specificity: Dogs diagnosed with cutaneous leishmaniasis in the Orinoco and Amazonas regions of southeastern Colombia.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but follow-up lasted 24 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hederagenin could inhibit pneumolysin (PLY) activity, potentially offering a new treatment strategy for pneumococcal diseases.
results_summary: The study found that hederagenin effectively inhibited PLY in vitro, demonstrating significant potential as a therapeutic agent for pneumococcal infections.
population_specificity: In vitro (laboratory setting, not human or animal subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immunomodulatory and anti-inflammatory efficacy of hederagenin-coated maghemite nanoparticles (HM) in treating atopic dermatitis (AD) and assess its physical and optical properties.
results_summary: HM treatment significantly reduced inflammatory cytokine expression in cells, diminished AD-like lesions in mice, and attenuated mast cell infiltration, epidermal thickening, and lymph node enlargement. HM also lowered mRNA expression of Th1, Th2, Th17 cytokines, and TSLP, showing better efficacy than uncoated maghemite nanoparticles (MP).
population_specificity: 8-week-old BALB/c mice with induced AD-like lesions and inflammatory-induced HaCaT and Jurkat cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance the aqueous solubility and tumor multidrug resistance (MDR) reversal activity of hederagenin derivatives, particularly HBQ, by designing and synthesizing new derivatives.
results_summary: PEGylated hederagenin derivatives, especially compound 10c, significantly improved aqueous solubility (18-657 fold) and maintained MDR reversal activity in vitro, inhibiting P-glycoprotein efflux function in resistant cancer cells. The study identified structure-activity relationships to guide future improvements in solubility and efficacy.
population_specificity: Multidrug-resistant oral epidermoid carcinoma (KBV) cells and paclitaxel-resistant breast carcinoma (MCF-7T) cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of Hederagenin (HDG) in Bleomycin-induced pulmonary fibrosis and its underlying molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: HDG reduced pulmonary dysfunction, pathological damage, collagen deposition, and levels of inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6), TGF-β1, and CTGF in a dose-dependent manner. It also inhibited the Ras/JNK/NFAT4 pathway, though this effect was reversed by a JNK activator.
population_specificity: Bleomycin-induced pulmonary fibrosis model (animal study, exact species not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a mixture (ADM) containing hederagenin, among other compounds, on atopic dermatitis (AD) skin lesions and the underlying molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that ADM, containing hederagenin, significantly reduced AD symptoms in mice, including epidermal thickness, mast cell infiltration, and levels of proinflammatory mediators and HPA axis hormones. ADM also suppressed ERK and JNK signaling pathways in vitro, reducing inflammatory markers in stimulated cells.
population_specificity: DNCB-induced ICR mice and TNF-α/IFN-γ-stimulated HaCaT cells.
effective_dosage: 0.5% ADM applied topically (specific frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Hederagenin (HED) could inhibit cardiac remodelling and dysfunction caused by diabetic cardiomyopathy, focusing on its effects on inflammatory signalling pathways.
results_summary: HED reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines, cardiac dysfunction, myocardial hypertrophy, and fibrosis in diabetic mice. It also inhibited NF-κB and Smads signalling pathways, decreasing TGF-β1 and collagen I expression.
population_specificity: Diabetic db/db mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-lung cancer effects of hederagenin and its hybrid compounds, particularly their efficacy against resistant non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) cell lines.
results_summary: Hederagenin showed limited efficacy, inhibiting only A549 tumor cell growth (IC50 > 10 μM), while its hybrid compound (13) demonstrated stronger inhibitory effects on multiple tumor cell lines and resistant NSCLC cells, suggesting a synergistic role with nitric oxide (NO).
population_specificity: In vitro tumor cell lines, including A549, H1975, and H1975-LTC NSCLC cells.
effective_dosage: Not specified (IC50 values provided: > 10 μM for hederagenin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Hederagenin on osteoclast formation and bone resorption in vitro and its therapeutic benefits in a mouse model of ovariectomy-induced bone loss.
results_summary: Hederagenin inhibited osteoclast formation and bone resorption in vitro by attenuating ROS production and MAPK signaling, and it effectively protected OVX mice from bone loss by reducing osteoclast activity.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized mice (simulating postmenopausal osteoporosis) and bone marrow-derived macrophages (BMMs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the therapeutic potential of hederagenin in cisplatin-resistant head and neck cancer (HNC) cells and characterize its molecular mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Hederagenin selectively induced cell death in both cisplatin-sensitive and cisplatin-resistant HNC cells by promoting mitochondrial membrane potential changes and apoptosis. It inhibited the Nrf2-ARE antioxidant pathway, enhanced ROS production, and activated intrinsic apoptotic pathways, with confirmed effects in xenograft models.
population_specificity: Cisplatin-sensitive and cisplatin-resistant head and neck cancer (HNC) cells and mouse tumor xenograft models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Hederagenin (HE) could attenuate cerebral ischaemia/reperfusion (CI/R) injury by reducing apoptosis, inflammation, and MLK3 signalling pathway activation in mice.
results_summary: HE treatment reduced brain infarct volume, improved neural function, and decreased apoptosis and inflammatory cytokine expression in the infarcted areas. It also inhibited the MLK3 signalling pathway, which contributes to CI/R damage via MAPK and NFκB pathways.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the ability of a novel α-hederagenin derivative (H6) to reverse multidrug resistance (MDR) in cancer cells by targeting P-glycoprotein (P-gp).
results_summary: H6 sensitized MDR cancer cells to paclitaxel and vincristine, increased drug accumulation without altering P-gp expression, stimulated P-gp ATPase activity, and enhanced paclitaxel efficacy in xenograft tumors. It also showed high binding affinity with P-gp.
population_specificity: KBV and MCF7/T cancer cell lines, and nude mice with KBV xenograft tumors.
interactions: Enhanced efficacy of paclitaxel and vincristine when co-administered with H6.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the hepatoprotective, anti-inflammatory, and anti-apoptotic effects of hederagenin on alcohol-induced liver injury in rats, focusing on AKT and MAPK signaling pathways.
results_summary: Hederagenin reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6, COX-2), modulated apoptosis-related proteins (increased Bcl-2, decreased Bax and p53), and influenced AKT and MAPK signaling, demonstrating protective effects against ethanol-induced liver damage.
population_specificity: Rats with alcohol-induced hepatotoxicity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiatherosclerotic effect of hederagenin and explore its mechanisms in a Wistar rat model of atherosclerosis.
results_summary: Hederagenin demonstrated multiple pharmacological activities, including improving lipid metabolism, reducing inflammation, and correcting endothelial dysfunction by modulating iNOS and eNOS levels and inhibiting the IKKβ/NF-κB pathway. It showed potential to inhibit or ameliorate atherosclerosis-related pathological changes.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with induced atherosclerosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the in vitro ability of hederagenin derivatives to inhibit Leishmania infantum growth and assess their potential as less toxic treatments for leishmaniasis.
results_summary: Several hederagenin derivatives (3, 4, 44, 49, and 52) showed micromolar-level activity against Leishmania infantum, with low toxicity to human cells. Derivatives 3, 4, 44, and 49 demonstrated higher selectivity and lower toxicity compared to the standard drug potassium antimonyl tartrate trihydrate.
population_specificity: In vitro study (Leishmania infantum and human cell lines BGM and HepG2).
effective_dosage: Not specified (activity measured at IC50 values of 2-12 μM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-inflammatory effects of hederagenin in vitro (RAW 264.7 cells) and in vivo (mouse hind paw edema model).
results_summary: Hederagenin inhibited inflammatory markers (iNOS, COX-2, NF-κB, NO, PGE2, TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6) in LPS-stimulated cells and reduced edema, skin thickness, inflammatory cell infiltration, and mast cell degranulation in mice.
population_specificity: Lipopolysaccharide-stimulated RAW 264.7 cells and carrageenan-treated mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanism by which hederagenin, the active ingredient in Fructus Akebiae extracts (FAE), exerts its antidepressant-like effects, specifically its interaction with monoamine transporters.
results_summary: FAE significantly inhibited serotonin (5-HT), norepinephrine (NE), and dopamine (DA) transporters in a dose- and time-dependent manner, increasing extracellular monoamine concentrations in the frontal cortex of rats, suggesting a novel triple monoamine transporter inhibition mechanism for its antidepressant activity.
population_specificity: Rat brain membrane preparations, HEK293 cells transfected with human monoamine transporters, and freely moving rats.
effective_dosage: 12.6, 25, and 50 mg/kg in vivo; 10 μM in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anticancer effects of Macranthoside B (a hederagenin saponin) in vitro and in vivo, focusing on its ability to inhibit cancer cell proliferation and induce apoptosis.
results_summary: MB inhibited cancer cell proliferation (IC50 10-20 µM) and reduced xenograft tumor volume/weight in mice. It induced apoptosis via mitochondrial pathways, evidenced by PARP degradation, caspase activation, and altered Bax/Bcl-2 ratios.
population_specificity: Cancer cells (in vitro) and nude mice with xenograft tumors (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antimutagenic and cytotoxic properties of Hederagenin and its glycosides from Kalopanax pictus stem bark.
results_summary: Hederagenin and its glycosides showed potent antimutagenic activity against aflatoxin B1 but not against MNNG, suggesting they may prevent metabolic activation of AFB1. Additionally, Hederagenin and its 3-O-glycosides exhibited cytotoxicity on various tumor cell lines, indicating potential for cancer treatment.
population_specificity: In vitro tumor cell lines (P-388, L-1210, U-937, HL-60, SNU-5, HepG2)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the antidepressant effects of natural products from Traditional Chinese Medicine, including Hederagenin, and their mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The abstract mentions Hederagenin as one of the active ingredients with potential antidepressant effects, but specific results regarding its efficacy or mechanisms are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of studies on natural products for depression).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of ultrasound-induced covalent conjugation of hemp protein isolate (HPI) with curcumin on its structural and functional properties.
results_summary: Ultrasound treatment altered HPI's structure, increasing free amino and sulfhydryl groups. Conjugation with curcumin significantly improved emulsifying activity, foam stability, solubility, and free radical scavenging capacity, and enabled gel formation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of dietary saponins, including Hederagenin, as effective and targeted treatments for obesity by examining their mechanisms and effects.
results_summary: The study found that dietary saponins, including Hederagenin, exhibit multiple anti-obesity effects such as inhibiting lipid synthesis, suppressing adipogenesis, and promoting fecal excretion of bile acids and triglycerides. They also act as pancreatic lipase inhibitors, appetite suppressants, and antioxidants.
population_specificity: Not specified (general obesity-related mechanisms discussed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the emulsion gel properties of soybean protein isolate (SPI) by incorporating hemp protein isolate (HPI) and ultrasonic treatment, exploring the mechanism behind these improvements.
results_summary: The study found that combining SPI and HPI at a ratio >6:4 under ultrasonic treatment (400 W) enhanced gel strength, water-holding capacity, and rheological properties, forming a stable protein-oil-coated network. Excessive ultrasonic power (600 W) degraded protein structure, while ratios <6:4 resulted in loose gels but improved digestibility.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: SPI:HPI ratios (e.g., >6:4, <6:4) and ultrasonic power (400 W, 600 W)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the functional attributes of hemp protein concentrate (HPC) using high-pressure homogenization (HPH) and pH-shifting-assisted Maillard conjugation techniques.
results_summary: The study found that HPH and pH-shifting methods significantly enhanced grafting degree, solubility, and functional properties of HPC, resulting in improved emulsion stability, foaming capacity, and antioxidant activity compared to untreated HPC and classical conjugates.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hemp protein supplementation, combined with a Mediterranean diet and exercise, could improve metabolic parameters in individuals prone to metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in lipid profiles (total cholesterol, HDL-C, LDL-C, and TAG levels) but no change in glucose levels. Plasma concentrations of certain amino acids increased while others decreased, suggesting metabolic modulation.
population_specificity: 23 patients with obesity and impaired glucose levels, following a Mediterranean diet and aerobic exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory and neuroprotective potential of hemp protein hydrolysates (HPHs) in a microglial cell model of neuroinflammation.
results_summary: The study found that HPHs significantly reduced proinflammatory gene expression (e.g., Tnfα, Ccr7, iNos, Nlrp3) and increased anti-inflammatory cytokine expression in LPS-induced BV-2 microglial cells, suggesting a shift toward an anti-inflammatory M2 phenotype.
population_specificity: Murine BV-2 microglial cells (in vitro model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the solubility and emulsification properties of hemp protein by developing a covalent complex with epigallocatechin-3-gallate (EGCG) and studying its structural and functional changes under heat treatment.
results_summary: The HPI-EGCG covalent complex showed improved solubility and emulsification properties, with a 2.77-fold increase in emulsification activity index (EAI) and a 1.21-fold increase in emulsion stability index (ESI). Structural changes included reductions in α-helix and β-helix content under heat treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: Maximum binding amount of HPI to EGCG was 29.18 μmol g-1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of hemp protein and soybean protein on glycemic response, insulin levels, and satiety relative to a carbohydrate control.
results_summary: Hemp protein dose-dependently lowered postprandial blood glucose and insulin concentrations, with effects comparable to soybean protein and superior to the carbohydrate control. No differences were observed between hemp and soy protein in glycemic or insulin responses.
population_specificity: Not specified beyond sample sizes (n=27 in experiment 1, n=16 in experiment 2).
effective_dosage: 20 g and 40 g of hemp protein (hemp20, hemp40) and soybean protein (soy20, soy40).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the leishmanicidal and cytotoxic potential of new hederagenin-derived 1,2,3-triazolyl compounds.
results_summary: Compound 19 showed strong cytotoxicity against human cancer cell lines (EC50 = 7.4-12.1 μM), while derivatives 1, 2, 5, and 17 exhibited high leishmanicidal activity (IC50 = 28.8, 25.9, 5.6, and 7.4 μM, respectively) with low toxicity and high selectivity. Compound 5 was particularly selective (1780 times more than commercial antimony drugs).
population_specificity: In vitro human cancer cell lines and Leishmania infantum.
effective_dosage: Not specified (tested at various concentrations in vitro).
interactions: Interaction with the enzyme CYP51Li noted for hederagenin and some derivatives (2, 5, and 17).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether inositol polyphosphate multikinase (IPMK) plays a role in free fatty acid (FFA)-induced insulin resistance in primary mouse hepatocytes.
results_summary: Excess FFA decreased IPMK expression, and IPMK blockade attenuated FFA-induced suppression of Akt phosphorylation. Overexpression of IPMK prevented FFA-induced insulin resistance, while knockout exacerbated it, suggesting IPMK as a potential therapeutic target.
population_specificity: Primary mouse hepatocytes (PMH)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effect of myo-inositol on cryopreserved boar semen, focusing on sperm quality, apoptosis, ROS levels, and fertility rates.
results_summary: Myo-inositol at 0.5 mg/mL improved sperm motility, acrosome integrity, and fertilization ability, while reducing pro-apoptotic gene expression and ROS levels. Lower concentrations also enhanced viability and reduced apoptosis.
population_specificity: Boar semen

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of SHIP2 (a 5'-inositol phosphatase) in Burkitt lymphoma cell survival and energy metabolism, particularly its connection to tonic BCR signals.
results_summary: The study found that SHIP2 deficiency increased apoptosis susceptibility and reduced proliferation in Burkitt lymphoma cells, linked to attenuated ATP production. SHIP2's enzymatic product PI(3,4)P2 was crucial for efficient energy metabolism, and inhibiting SHIP proteins made cells more vulnerable to PI3K inhibition.
population_specificity: Burkitt lymphoma cells (in vitro models)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare metabolite profiles, including myo-inositol, in individuals with treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS) versus non-TRS and healthy controls to explore potential neuroinflammatory components.
results_summary: The study found higher myo-inositol levels in the anterior cingulate cortex in TRS and ultra-TRS groups compared to non-TRS and healthy controls, suggesting a possible neuroinflammatory association, though results are preliminary due to limited datasets.
population_specificity: Individuals with treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS), ultra-TRS (clozapine-resistant), non-TRS schizophrenia, and healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the correlations between INPP4B and digestive system tumors and its roles in tumor development, diagnosis, treatment, and prognosis.
results_summary: INPP4B expression varies across digestive system tumors (low in gastric, colon, pancreatic, and liver cancers; high in esophageal, colon, pancreatic, and gallbladder cancers) and is involved in tumor development through gene expression and signal transduction regulation. The study suggests INPP4B as a potential molecular target for diagnosis, treatment, and prognosis evaluation.
population_specificity: Digestive system tumors (gastric, colon, pancreatic, liver, esophageal, gallbladder cancers)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of HERPUD1 in regulating mitochondrial function and tumor cell migration by controlling ITPR3-dependent Ca2+ signals, which involves inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate receptor (ITPR3).
results_summary: HERPUD1 deficiency enhanced mitochondrial activity and increased intracellular Ca2+ release, which was prevented by ITPR3 antagonist xestospongin C or Ca2+ chelator BAPTA-AM. HERPUD1 expression reduced tumor cell migration by controlling ITPR3-mediated Ca2+ signals, and its deficiency increased migratory capacity via reactive oxygen species-dependent activation of paxillin and FAK proteins.
population_specificity: Tumor cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how the IRE1α-JNK axis regulates lipid metabolism in bovine hepatocytes and its potential role in reducing NEFA-induced lipid accumulation.
results_summary: The study found that targeting the IRE1α-JNK axis reduced NEFA-induced lipid accumulation in bovine hepatocytes by modulating lipogenesis and fatty acid oxidation (FAO). Inhibition of JNK and IRE1α downregulated lipogenesis genes and upregulated FAO genes, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for fatty liver in dairy cows.
population_specificity: Dairy cows (healthy and those with fatty liver) and primary calf hepatocytes.
effective_dosage: NEFA (1.2 mM) for hepatocyte treatments; specific inositol dosage not mentioned.
study_duration: Hepatocytes treated for up to 12 hours; overall study duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of myo-inositol (MI) supplementation in mitigating cisplatin-induced acute kidney injury (AKI) in mice and human renal tubular epithelial cells.
results_summary: The study found that exogenous MI significantly attenuated kidney injury and cell damage caused by cisplatin, reducing excessive apoptosis and lowering levels of injury markers like MIOX, KIM-1, and NGAL in both mice and HK-2 cells.
population_specificity: Male Kunming mice and human renal tubular epithelial cell line HK-2 cells.
effective_dosage: Mice: 150 mg/kg, 300 mg/kg, 600 mg/kg; HK-2 cells: 200 µM, 400 µM, 800 µM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the signaling properties and therapeutic potential of inositol pyrophosphates, particularly 5PP-InsP5 and InsP8, in regulating cellular processes and their implications for treating metabolic disorders.
results_summary: The study found that inositol pyrophosphates, especially 5PP-InsP5 and InsP8, play key roles in regulating cell death, energy homeostasis, and cytoskeletal dynamics. Blocking the 5PP-InsP5/InsP8 signaling pathway showed therapeutic benefits in preclinical studies, suggesting potential for treating metabolic disorders.
population_specificity: Preclinical studies (not specified if human or animal models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether valproate (VPA) depletes inositol by phosphorylating myo-inositol-3-phosphate synthases (MIPS) or through another mechanism.
results_summary: The study found that VPA does not significantly phosphorylate MIPS but instead reduces MIPS expression, leading to inositol depletion. Protein kinases PKC and CKII showed low specificity toward MIPS, suggesting an alternative mechanism for inositol reduction.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or cellular models, as human subjects are not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether myo-inositol could moderate dysregulated placental palmitic acid (PA) and oleic acid (OA) metabolism induced by glucose, leptin, or insulin in gestational diabetes (GDM).
results_summary: Myo-inositol attenuated most glucose-, leptin-, and insulin-induced alterations in placental lipid metabolism, except for acylcarnitines, which were unaffected or exacerbated. The effects were consistent across GDM status and fetal sex subgroups.
population_specificity: Placental explants from 21 women (with and without GDM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of pinitol on osteoporosis in ovariectomized mice and elucidate its mechanism of action in vivo.
results_summary: Pinitol significantly suppressed serum BALP and TRAcP activities, improved femur weight, cellular bone rate, and Ca/P content, and elevated DCI content in serum and bone marrow in OVX mice, demonstrating anti-osteoporosis activity.
population_specificity: Four-week-old female ovariectomized ICR mice (postmenopausal osteoporosis model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of myo-inositol in promoting brain development and synapse formation in infants and its bioactivity in mature brain tissue.
results_summary: Myo-inositol was found to promote synapse abundance in human and rat neurons, enhance neuronal responsiveness to transsynaptic interactions, and increase excitatory postsynaptic sites in the maturing cortex of mice. It also increased the number and size of postsynaptic specializations and excitatory synapse density in mature brain tissue.
population_specificity: Human milk samples across global populations, infant brain development, and mature brain tissue (tested in mice and organotypic slice cultures).

study_goal: To explore the mechanisms of moxibustion at Governor Vessel acupoints on the IRE1/XBP1 pathway in hippocampal CA1 region of rats with vascular dementia (VD).
results_summary: Moxibustion improved cognitive function in VD rats by regulating the IRE1/XBP1 pathway, reducing pro-apoptotic protein Bax, and increasing anti-apoptotic protein Bcl-2, leading to decreased nerve cell apoptosis. The effects were comparable to medication (nimodipine).
population_specificity: Male SD rats with induced vascular dementia.
effective_dosage: Moxibustion at "Baihui" (GV20), "Dazhui" (GV14), and "Fengfu" (GV16) for 20 min each point, once daily for 6 days/week; nimodipine at 2 mg•kg-1•d-1 in 3 daily doses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of arginine-silicate-inositol complex (ASI) and phytase on the performance of laying hens, focusing on production metrics like hen house production, egg weight, and feed intake.
results_summary: The study found that the ASI complex, particularly when combined with phytase (T5), significantly improved hen house production (95.06%) compared to the control (91.67%). However, no significant differences were observed in egg weight or egg mass across treatments, and phytase supplementation improved feed conversion ratio (FCR) in T5 compared to controls.
population_specificity: 90 laying hens, 25 weeks old
effective_dosage: 1000 mg/kg arginine-silicate-inositol complex (49.5% arginine, 8.2% silicone, 25% inositol)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether D-chiro-Inositol could improve the condition of patients with simple endometrial hyperplasia without atypia by reducing endometrial thickness and related symptoms.
results_summary: D-chiro-Inositol significantly reduced endometrial thickness from 10.82 ± 1.15 mm to 6.9 ± 1.06 mm over six months (p < 0.001) and improved heavy menstrual bleeding and menstruation length.
population_specificity: Women with simple endometrial hyperplasia without atypia and related symptoms, including abnormal uterine bleeding.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether myo-Inositol (myo-Ins) differentially improves metabolic, endocrine, and gynecological parameters in women with different PCOS phenotypes (hyperandrogenic vs. non-hyperandrogenic).
results_summary: Myo-Ins significantly improved metabolic and endocrine parameters in hyperandrogenic PCOS (H-PCOS) but had negligible effects in non-hyperandrogenic PCOS (NH-PCOS). It also increased endometrial thickness in H-PCOS.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), categorized into hyperandrogenic (phenotypes A, B, C) and non-hyperandrogenic (phenotype D) subgroups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how mammalian inositol pyrophosphate (PP-InsP) levels change in response to oxidative stress and the role of quinone drugs like β-lapachone in modulating PP-InsP metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that PP-InsP levels decrease upon exposure to oxidative stressors in HCT116 cells and that β-lapachone treatment alters PP-InsP levels in an oxygen-dependent manner, requiring NQO1 bioactivation. ATP concentration changes did not directly correlate with PP-InsP reductions in NQO1-deficient cells.
population_specificity: HCT116 and MDA-MB-231 cancer cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of an arginine silicate inositol complex (ASI) on egg quality, shell strength, and blood biochemical traits in laying hens, and how substituting inositol with phytase influenced these outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that ASI supplementation significantly improved eggshell thickness, shell weight, and breaking strength, while phytase substitution further enhanced yolk weight and blood serum levels of non-HDL, calcium, and phosphorus.
population_specificity: 90 Lohmann Brown laying hens, 26 weeks old
effective_dosage: 1000 mg/kg arginine-silicate-inositol mixture (49.5% arginine, 8.2% silicone, 25% inositol)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of inositol supplementation in preventing or reducing the severity of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).
results_summary: Inositol supplementation significantly reduced the incidence of GDM, improved glycemic control (fasting glucose, 1-h, and 2-h OGTT results), and lowered risks of pregnancy-induced hypertension, preterm birth, and neonatal hypoglycemia.
population_specificity: Pregnant women at high risk of GDM (1,319 participants across 7 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Houttuynia cordata, through modulation of inositol trisphosphate receptors (IP3Rs) and intracellular Ca2+ signaling, could alleviate asthma-related airway remodeling.
results_summary: The study found that H. cordata essential oil rectified disrupted Ca2+ signaling, mitigated asthma development, and prevented airway narrowing by downregulating IP3R expression, with houttuynin identified as a potential bioactive component.
population_specificity: Primary human bronchial smooth muscle cells and a house dust mite-sensitized asthma model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate phosphate ester analogs (methylene, fluoromethylene, and difluoromethylene) of d-glucose 6-phosphate (G6P) as potential inhibitors or substrate analogs for 1l-myo-inositol-1-phosphate synthase (mIPS), a key enzyme in myo-inositol metabolism.
results_summary: The study described the synthesis of G6P analogs and their application in studying mIPS, suggesting these compounds could serve as inhibitors or substrate mimics, potentially aiding in targeting mIPS for therapeutic purposes. The docking approach helped rationalize the observed behavior of these analogs.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining exercise with lysine-inositol VB12 therapy could effectively promote height growth in children with idiopathic short stature (ISS).
results_summary: The study found that regular exercise combined with lysine-inositol VB12 significantly improved growth velocity, height, and serum growth-related hormone levels in children with ISS compared to the control group. The intervention was clinically safe, with no significant adverse biochemical differences between groups.
population_specificity: Children with idiopathic short stature (ISS) (N=60, aged not specified).
effective_dosage: 10 mL of lysine-inositol VB12 oral solution, twice daily (bid).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of the rice inositol polyphosphate kinase gene (OsIPK2) in phosphorus (Pi) homeostasis and root system architecture (RSA) adjustment in response to varying environmental Pi levels.
results_summary: Overexpression of OsIPK2 altered inositol polyphosphate profiles, increased Pi accumulation, and affected root growth under different Pi conditions. It also misregulated Pi-starvation-induced genes and altered acid phosphatase activities, indicating its role in Pi homeostasis and RSA adjustment.
population_specificity: Transgenic rice and Arabidopsis plants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of nutrient supplements, including myo-inositol, for improving fertility outcomes in women with infertility, either trying to conceive spontaneously or using medically assisted reproduction (MAR).
results_summary: Myo-inositol increased clinical pregnancy rates in women with PCOS and/or undergoing MAR compared to placebo, standard, or no treatment (OR 1.52), though the certainty of evidence was very low. No significant adverse effects or risks were reported.
population_specificity: Women with PCOS and/or undergoing medically assisted reproduction (MAR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize findings from human intervention studies on the interactions between phytic acid, phytase, and micronutrient bioavailability, particularly focusing on iron and zinc.
results_summary: Most studies showed that exogenous phytase or dephytinized foods improved iron and zinc bioavailability, while phytic acid-rich diets reduced their bioavailability.
population_specificity: Human populations, particularly those with disease-associated malnutrition or in developing countries consuming phytic acid-rich diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the function and mechanisms of myo-inositol (MI) in ameliorating renal interstitial fibrosis (RIF) using mouse models and HK-2 cells.
results_summary: MI treatment reduced pathological alterations of RIF in mice, downregulated fibrosis markers, and reversed TGF-β1-induced effects in HK-2 cells, suggesting MI may mitigate RIF by inhibiting TGF-β1-induced epithelial transdifferentiation and PI3K/AKT activation.
population_specificity: UUO-induced renal fibrosis mouse model and TGF-β1-treated HK-2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Myo-inositol, alone and in combination with selenium, in reducing thyroid autoantibody levels and restoring TSH levels in patients with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
results_summary: The study found that Myo-inositol alone and in combination with selenium did not significantly reduce TPOAb or TgAb levels over a 6-month treatment period, with confidence intervals crossing zero.
population_specificity: Patients with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and euthyroidism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the relationship between macrophage activation and glucose metabolism reprogramming, focusing on the role of PI3K/AKT and mTOR/HIF-1 signaling pathways in macrophage polarization.
results_summary: The study suggests that shifting macrophage metabolism from glycolysis to oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) can inhibit pro-inflammatory M1 macrophage activation and promote anti-inflammatory M2 macrophage activation, potentially offering therapeutic benefits for acute liver failure (ALF). The PI3K/AKT and mTOR/HIF-1 pathways were identified as key regulators of this metabolic reprogramming.
population_specificity: The study is theoretical and based on a literature review; no specific human or animal population was studied.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of point-of-care tests, including inositol phosphoglycan-P, for short-term prediction of preeclampsia in the second or third trimester.
results_summary: Only one study investigated inositol phosphoglycan-P, but no specific results or efficacy data for inositol were reported in the abstract. Meta-analysis was only possible for glycosylated fibronectin, not inositol.
population_specificity: Pregnant women at risk for preeclampsia in the second or third trimester.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway in prostate cancer and discuss the potential of its inhibitors as treatment targets.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about Inositol's effects, focusing instead on the PI3K/AKT pathway's role in prostate cancer and the potential of its inhibitors.
population_specificity: Male patients with prostate cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify genes associated with hypervirulence and IFNγ production in Cryptococcus neoformans, including the role of the inositol sensor ITR4.
results_summary: The study found that ITR4 polymorphisms are associated with IFNγ production and hypervirulence in Cryptococcus neoformans, with the itr4Δ mutant recapitulating the hypervirulence phenotype and affecting IFNγ-associated gene expression.
population_specificity: Cryptococcus neoformans clinical isolates and a cryptococcosis mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a nutritional formulation containing myo-inositol, probiotics, and micronutrients, taken preconception and during pregnancy, improves maternal and infant health outcomes compared to standard micronutrient supplementation.
results_summary: The intervention did not affect gestational glycemia but reduced preterm delivery, operative delivery for delayed second stage, major postpartum hemorrhage, and rapid infant weight gain, while potentially shortening time to conception in overweight women.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their offspring in the UK, Singapore, and New Zealand.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of inositol in fibrometabolism and pulmonary fibrosis, particularly its potential therapeutic effects on idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).
results_summary: The study found that inositol supplementation downregulated ASS1 deficiency-mediated signaling pathways, reduced cell invasiveness in IPF lung fibroblasts, and mitigated fibrotic lesions and collagen deposition in a bleomycin-induced mouse model.
population_specificity: IPF patients (lung fibroblasts) and a bleomycin-induced lung fibrosis mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential positive effects of inositol, among other substances, on patients with Type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
